content.body: Hixie: <html class="split (index|chapter)"> is there now
fwiw, this will cause pubrules issues down the road though I suppose the W3C edition can simply omit the classes altogether
They don't like classes on <html>?
http://www.w3.org/2005/07/pubrules?uimode=filter&uri=
"All normative representations must either:
validate as either HTML 4.x or as some version of XHTML that is a W3C Recommendation, or
(for non-Recommendations) validate as XHTML+RDFa; see RDFa in XHTML: Syntax and Processing (Team Contacts please see the Communications Team to propose additional exceptions)."
Guess that one's gonna have to be scrapped, huh?
The front matter must appear at the beginning of the body of the document, within <div class="head">.

This section describes the status of this document at the time of its publication. Other documents may supersede this document. A list of current W3C publications and the latest revision of this technical report can be found in the W3C technical reports index at http://www.w3.org/TR/.
That's not conforming HTML 5, it's almost certainly misuse of <em> by HTML 5 standards.
. . . overall, I think these publication rules are going to have to be hacked a bunch anyway for HTML 5.  :P
Philip`: class="" is invalid in HTML4
(on <html>)
You could put it on the <body> instead.
Doesn't make much difference.
I know that's valid, because MediaWiki puts a new class on the <body> every time someone's bored.
Also, MediaWiki contributors are frequently bored.
Wait, is the W3C version of the HTML 5 spec seriously going to be published as an HTML 4 document?
the w3c isn't convinced that html5 is compatible enough, or something
i dunno, i stopped listening around the time they said that it wasn't obvious that we should publish html5 as html5
that's a big vote of confidence for a standard
it's more just an indication of how out of touch the w3c management is
(with a couple of exceptions, who argued in favour of using html5)
the whatwg version has used html5 for years
eat your own dog food, they say
In what way is it less compatible than HTML 4?
beats me
html4 used html4 since the earliest drafts
it just seems like the w3c management is anti-html5 to me
NIH syndrome?
could be
dunno
or just upset about the history
or maybe they're just really that far out of touch
who knows

Well, they kind of had it forced on them against their will, I guess.  Not likely that they'll completely change their attitude toward the direction HTML should head just because the browser vendors force their hand.
and frankly who cares :-)
I get the impression that W3C involvement here is basically political and nobody important in the WHATWG really cares too much what they think.
i think the situation is a lot more subtle than that
at least speaking for me, it's more that i don't care _who_ has feedback, so it makes no difference to me whether it's w3c staff who think something or some random web author
since only the technical merits of the feedback matter
it seems the first WD version of XHTML 1 has been published in the "in-development" xhtml 1 format http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/WD-html-in-xml-19981205/
But XHTML 2 and so on are all published in XHTML <= 1.1, right?
XHTML 2, 1.2, whatever.  The ones nobody ever used.
XHTML 2 couldn't have been published in XHTML 2 because it wasn't backwards compatible
XHTML 2 working drafts were published in xhtml 1.0 http://www.w3.org/TR/2002/WD-xhtml2-20020805/
(maybe they should have realised that it was doomed at that point, but oh well)
and the last XHTML 2 WD was published using xhtml 1.0 too
AryehGregor: I care about helping W3C management make good decisions
Okay, okay, I shouldn't have been so inflammatory, my bad.
ah, it's so nice to have full access to the dom tree from python with evaluated javascript and all
HTML5 will proceed with or without the W3C, but probably better with than without.
I'm not sure the publication format of HTML5 is very important, but it does seem like it would make a better impression to publish HTML5 in HTML5
Although I have to wonder if maybe the W3C has just gotten too bureaucratic and closed to be a good web standards body anymore.
The WHATWG procedure seems obviously better to me.  Although I'm probably biased.
Both because I'm not part of any W3C member organization, and because I'm one of those crazy wiki/open-source hippies.  :)
creating the HTML WG, adopting HTML5, and ending the XHTML2 WG all seem like steps in the right direction
Having w3c on board helps with the patent situation, doesn't it?
in fact you can join the HTML WG freely without being part of any Member organization
Yeah, but we're still talking about an organization where to subscribe to the bloody mailing list I had to find and fill out multiple forms and wait two weeks.
(www-style allows open subscription, why not public-html?)
Dashiva, is anyone particularly concerned about HTML-related patents?
AryehGregor: www-style is not the csswg's list
Sigh.
Right.
Hidden stuff.
the main advantages of working with the W3C are: (1) patent policy; (2) Microsoft is willing to participate; (3) the W3C still has a lot of prestige in the eyes of the general public
(though they are using it a lot, which is good)
Hmm, yeah, (2) is certainly a good point.
Haven't seen any Microsoft employees posting to whatwg.
isn't really convinced about (3), and (2) is because of (1), so it's really just (1), imho
AryehGregor: Apple had a bunch of HTML-related patents which we disclosed and agreed to license RF as part of the HTML WG publication and patent review process
othermaciej, interesting.
including a patent on <canvas>
Ah.
That's valuable, then.
(3) isn't important, if HTML5 is the future then people will have to accept it whether they like it or not.
It's good that XHTML was shut down, though.
So if only we abolished software patents, we wouldn't need the W3C anymore?  :)
I'm not saying W3C is a perfect organization, but I believe it is moving in the right direction, and working with them seems worthwhile if it doesn't impose an unreasonable cost
Sure.
it's imposed a pretty high cost
i don't know how much cost is considered reasonable
I believe 3 is important for public organisations
I would also add that many specs that are very important but less visible than HTML5 are proceeding quite happily in the W3C without giant political fights
Well, (3) doesn't matter in the long term, because HTML 5 will win in the long term and everyone will have to recognize it sooner or later.
they might forbidden using HTML5 on their websites if it wasn't a W3C spec
AryehGregor: not all patents impacting software are software patents
H.264 is protected by DSP patents
Rik`: is this the same organisations who use <embed> when youtube says that's how you embed video?
Rik`: or heck, is this the same organisations who use window.open()?
If a patent prohibits the distribution of some type of software, then as far as I'm concerned it's a software patent.  I'm not sure what else "software patent" would mean, in fact.
Rik`: or element.innerHTML?
or showModalDialog()?
or all the other things W3C never specced?
AryehGregor: I don't think win or lose is the right framing - clearly HTML5 is being implemented by browsers and adopted by content authors, and I don't think anyone wants or expects to reverse that
AryehGregor: `software patent' = the patent classification, according to the USPTO
I think a lot of people want to reverse HTML5's success.
the question is a matter of how positive and peaceful the rollout can be
Hixie: the only process to check that the policy is respected is the HTML validator
if there is an active resistance movement, that would be a bad thing for the Web platform, even if there is no hope of truly scuttling the effort

jcranmer, hmm, didn't know there was such a thing.  Well, then "software-related patent" or whatever term you'd like me to use.  At least they shouldn't exist insofar as they prohibit the creation of computing standards, file formats, etc.
Rik`: that says <embed> is bad, but people still use <embed>
othermaciej, yes, I agree.  I'm just being overly confrontational (not that there's anyone here I'm confronting).
I haven't seen a lot of Youtube videos on such sites
Anyway, I don't think most of this contradicts my original point, which is that getting HTML5 approved as a W3C standard is mostly just a political move.
Hixie, even public organizations?  Wasn't there a big breakthrough recently when the US government allowed its websites to use cookies?
Just because everyone uses it doesn't mean some crazy government bureaucrats will allow the government to use it.  :)
AryehGregor: gov'ts have been embedding flash and videos and the like for plenty of time
standards are political
I guess they don't really have any choice, if they want to post videos . . .
AryehGregor: and i doubt that if the world moved forward, they would continue to stay in 1999 until such time as w3c stamped the spec
actually, standards are more like international relations than politics
from what I can tell, gov'ts are rather technologically incompetent
they just use <insert some standard utility here>
you can be a realist or an idealist, but ultimately there's no direct enforcement for defecting, so it has to be in everyone's interest to cooperate
or the effort fails
so you can compare the W3C to the UN
othermaciej: do you have a blue helmet ?
it starts as a collection of its constituents, but eventually develops its own institutional interests which at times also need to be considered
Rik`: not a bad analogy - responsible for keeping the peace, but little power to enforce it and not much respect from the locals
So what's the w3c equivalent of the human rights' council coup?
the TAG
maybe WAI? I could make a case for either, but this is getting to be a silly metaphor
I18N + TAG + WAI + QA (when it was still existing)
Are we going to come up with an analogy to the fact that China and Russia are members of the HRC?  :)
http://beta.w3.org/Consortium/mission
why oh why must they plug twitter at the bottom of that page?!
what about the security council?
For HTML5, the W3C is the General Assembly and the Steering Committee is the Security Council.  :)
does anyone have a link handy to Mike Smith's draft or Lachy's authoring guide?
hmm. there's a CC logo on the ODRL front page. I wonder how ODRL relates to CC/REL
othermaciej, http://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/
Lachy: s/contain/contains/ in "and the body, which contain all of the page’s content"
Lachy: also, when you mention RDF, you could also mention DocBook and say that HTML falls in between
after all, HTML is pretty light on semantics and, therefore, not exemplary of a semantic markup language
s/RDF/RTF/
I can't checkout v.nu code, svn: Could not open the requested SVN filesystem
lazni: which svn URL?
svn co http://svn.versiondude.net/whattf/build/trunk/ build
lazni: that URL is no more
lazni: do I still have documentation out there that gives that URL?
lazni: see http://about.validator.nu/#src
the last time I go to http://about.validator.nu/#src it was there
sorry
lazni: CVSDude changed their system
line 281 of html5lib/python3/src/html5lib/treebuilders/etree_lxml.py uses python2 syntax            print docStr
are we porting html5lib to Python 3?
Someone seemingly started
Is there a better approach than maintaining two parallel versions of all the code?
Philip`: writing a translator that converts one into the other
language to language compilation FTW!
I'm not sure that mantra applies to everyone :)
Python already has a tool to do that, but I don't know if it's perfect or if some manual fixup is needed on the output
does Python 3 have a switch statement yet?
Philip`, it's not perfect at all, but does quite a bit of work; see diveintopython3
hsivonen: It has if/elif - what more do you want?
Philip`: what are the perf characteristics of an if/elif chain compared to switch in C or Java?
hsivonen, I don't think so: http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3103/
at least when the switch has a contiguous range of integer cases, switch compiler more nicely
Depends on the compiler, since surely it could optimise "if x == 1: ... elif x == 2: ..." without requiring the programmer to use special syntax
(I'm sure it doesn't, but it could)
wonders if non-contiguous switch compiler to anything nicer than if-else in GCC
We have a python3 branch of html5lib because I hacked one together one weekend
s/compiler/compiles/
You can just use an array of functions in Python if you want contiguous indexed switching
I guess if there is a bug in it like that it is because a) that is a file I didn't get to yet or b) something got checked in on the wrong file
OTOH the Python3 branch is not really maintained yet
you didn't use 2to3?
if you have functions, you can't use the fall through tricks you can with switch cases
I /did/ use 2to3 but it's not magic
thought 2to3 knows well about print()
It will replace the print statements but it can't guess where you need byte arrays and where you need strings, for example
gah, there's tons of interference on my local network
(like said that file may never have been converted, or that print statement may have slipped in by accident later on)
oh ok
i should not be getting 35ms pings to a box i can throw rocks at in less time than 35ms
suspects that isn't true
hello, is there an easy way to determine (serverside wise would be better, but client side also ok) whether the client supports the html5 audio-tag?
you shouldn't need to, generally speaking -- just put whatever your fallback is inside the <audio> element
ah cool

hsivonen: In the non-contiguous case, it looks like GCC sometimes does a normal table jump (if you've just got a few holes, which it makes jump to code that does nothing) and sometimes does a kind of binary-tree lookup (though not really binary, but anyway it's not just a linear search)
I get tons of interference with the proprietary wireless dongle of my home mouse. I'm very annoyed at Logitech's failure to use bluetooth
and I guess sometimes it will just do a linear search if it thinks that's fastest
at least Macs have decent bluetooth antennas
Philip`: cool
Philip`: thanks
i wonder what this interference is coming from
(I mean "looks like" in terms of the assembly output of a simple test program, and "guess" in terms of having no evidence)
good to know my use of switch isn't all in vein
it's been going on longer than a microwave would, so it's not the neighbours microwaving something
Intravenous switch?
there are about 25 wifi networks in range, which probably doesn't help
s/vein/vain/
Hixie: Try logging in to the others' router configuration interfaces (with a compatible browser) and then switch them all off
or juggle the channels
or change their channel assignments to leave a nice big gap for you
WRT54G password is linksys:admin
Hixie: consistency note; 4.6.25 Usage summary ruby example doesn’t include closing </rt> and </rp>, and #the-rp-element example does (no big deal, but just in case)
boblet: intentional
boblet: the examples aren't supposed to be consistent
Hixie: actually I was happy to see the usage summary example, b/c all those elements in a small space was a little much last time I marked some up (XHTML-goggles)
ok 1.3s to the router, which is literaly within kicking distance, is ridiculous
recommends gigabit ethernet
i am indeed tempted to get out the ethernet cable
(i'm using a laptop, the proximity to the router is coincidental)

(By the way, by "a kind of binary tree lookup" I don't mean there's an actual tree data structure - it's just code, kind of like "if (x < 10) { if (x < 5) ... else ... } else if (x < 20) { ... }", maybe with a branch for each contiguous section or something)
speaking of routers, the UI for setting up a VPN between two Linksys boxes is ridiculously complex
wonders if the UI is designed for the people who spec the protocols at the IETF
is glad he hardly has issues
my six or so devices can all happily connect

Lachy: if you’re there I’d like to ask you about HTML5Doctors section article; “typically with a heading” is quite different to the “With very few exceptions, section should not be used if there is no natural heading for it”

that defn wouldn’t cover 4.6.26 Footnotes “longer annotation” example (section containing only

)
accidentally DNS spoofs himself and gets a MITM message from ssh
registers his ethernet address in DNS...
boblet, how are they very different?
Lachy: level of strictness
anyway, the point of the article was to try and discourage the common misuse of section as merely a wrapper
Lachy: eg I’ve got previous/next page links in a section (related content), but it has no heading. This seems correct for “typically”, but probably not for “should not”
Lachy: yeah I wondered if the language was stronger (well, to me) than the spec for that reason
<footer> might be more appropriate for the prev/next links
Lachy: Since the article doesn’t list any, could you give an example or two of ok exceptions?
Lachy: it’s a <section> in the page <footer> :)
web applications generally have more use for headingless sections
the gmail inbox was mentioned in here as one such example recently
or perhaps the center column of facebook where it lists all your friends statuses
Lachy: so would eg the typical <div id="main"> and <div id="sidebar"> be appropriate as <section>s? (assuming sidebar contains disparate content so <aside> isn’t appropriate)
on one hand they’re layout hooks, but otoh they are logical chunks of related content
I'm not sure that gmail is a good example
<div id="main"> shoud generally keep using <div> if it's just used as a wrapper to separate it from the header and footer
I think if I were using AT I would want headings on each section so that I could quickly navigate between different parts of the UI
wow, ok
(the could be hidden using CSS ofc)
<aside> is for sidebar, unless we introduce <sidebar> as was discussed recently
jgraham: ok, that’s kinda the rule of thumb I’m working to after reading the HTML5Doctors article
Lachy: <aside> couldn’t include non-related content tho (list of site-wide popular links etc), right?
why not?
wouldn't side-wide popular links be <nav>?

Hixie: you said I should just put the fallback code inside the audio-tag, but <audio id='sound'><object id='sound'></object></audio> won't give me access by id if the audio-tag is not avaiable, so I guess I have to give different ids and test via javascript which is usable!? If the audio-tag is avaible would the object be avaiable by id?
Ox032F: if you're using javascript, you'll have to test to see if the element is supported anyway, since it's unlikely that your plugin will have the same API as the <audio> element
boblet, what do you mean by "site-wide popular links"?
thats not a problem, I'm testing for Play(), play() and DoPlay() already
I thought maybe it was a blog roll or something

Lachy: I perceive <aside> should only contain tangental info that’s relevant to the <article>/<section>. Weblogs often have a grabbag of random stuff on every page’s sidebar; imported twitter posts, site search, most popular articles, recent site-wide comments etc
Lachy: I would have thought these aren’t relevant to the <article>, so shouldn’t be in an <aside> …?
seems like it would go in the body's aside.  <body><header/><div id=main/> <aside>[all that stuff in here]</aside></body>
Lachy: aah indeed. d’oh
I was gonna comment on the woork HTML5 cheatsheet mistakes: http://woork.blogspot.com/2009/09/html-5-visual-cheat-sheet-by-woork.html maybe I shouldn’t :x
angry? how about :|
Ox032F, you should not use duplicate IDs
Ox032F, 'cause both end up in the DOM
ok
Ox032F, also, if the <object> plug-in automatically starts playing you have a problem as it will do so in new browsers too
only if they don't implement the spec properly
the spec says <object> inside <video>/<audio> doesn't instantiate
shouldn't <parameter autoplay='false'> prevent that?
Hixie, ah, I forgot it changed
apparently all blog commenters aren't OK with the new no-space spec titling :-(
i cannot _believe_ how much time has been wasted on the presence or existence of that space
if i knew zeldman's request was going to cause this much pain, i'd have said no
Hixie: that's the danger of announcing that a bikeshed is being built in the back yard
virtuelv: I tried to announce it had been built and painted already.
i don't really understand why anyone cares
Hixie: trying to make "HTML 5" and "HTML5" mean different things was too obscure
People who care about specifications are likely to care about accuracy and preciseness and getting things exactly right, and caring about all the little details
Hixie: also, people want to know what's "right"
hsivonen: when i said they meant different things i figured people would take it as a ridiculous joke
Try a different community if you want people who don't care about this stuff :-)
(Please remove some redundant uses of "care" in the previous sentences)
Hixie: you are in the business of writing *precise* specs, so that kind of things don't work as jokes
Hixie: It doesn't seem any more ridiculous than e.g. Perl and perl meaning different things
"Perl" and "perl" mean different things?
hsivonen: apparently
Hixie: Perl means the language and perl means the implementation
Perl is the language, perl is the standard implementation
and PERL means you're stupid and can be ignored and/or ridiculed because you can't even capitalise the name correctly
and perl is the only thing that can parse Perl, IIRC.
boblet, that HTML5 visual cheat sheet includes elements that were dropped a long time ago
guesses Perl is undecidable like C++
like <datatemplate>, <rule> and <nest>
Lachy: apart from adactio’s I haven’t seen a cheatsheet that wasn’t riddled with errors :/
hober: http://search.cpan.org/~adamk/PPI-1.206/lib/PPI.pm apparently does quite a good job at parsing Perl independently of perl
Lachy: writing a comment now—will add those
(to the list of mistakes)
hsivonen: What do you mean by "undecidable" in this context?
For C++, compiling source into an executable is undecidable
but Perl doesn't really compile like that
boblet, I'm guessing he's working from some old draft or somethign
his source is stated
otherwise, I can't figure out how he would have ended up with those long gone elements
it is w3schools
Philip`: that you can't build an AST from a source file without auxiliary information
Lachy: maybe the W3Schools cheatsheet? :D
hah, kabutta
http://ovh.dl.sourceforge.net/sourceforge/junit/junit-4.4.jar times out, http://ncu.dl.sourceforge.net/project/junit/junit/4.4/junit-4.4.jar works
lazni: could be a temporary problem
unless ovh has stopped being a sf.net mirror
I think you can use the general link instead of hardcoding the mirror
I tried nchc and it directed  me to http://downloads.sourceforge.net/sourceforge/junit/junit-4.4.jar?download&failedmirror=nchc.dl.sourceforge.net
ah, well, that sucks. No-one should use W3schools as a source for anything :-(
lazni: do they use sane redirects instead of serving an HTML file form the general link?
Ox032F: set the id on the <audio>, test support with if ('play' in audio)
hsivonen: In Perl you can write 'BEGIN { undecidable_function() } syntax error' so it seems boringly true that you can't parse the whole file decidably
new <aside> text is up
with a new example
Ox032F: else use audio.firstChild (the object)
it looks sane, I used wget nchc.dl...
At least C++ forces you to do interesting crazy template stuff before it's impossible to compile
actually, is there a definitive list of HTML5 elements, something like http://www.w3schools.com/tags/html5.asp but actually correct?
boblet, http://simon.html5.org/html5-elements is maintained
lazni: OK. thanks. I guess I need to recheck the sf.net mirroring stuff
is it a *cheat* sheet if it's maintained? :-)
annevk2: great—that’s actually what I’d been using. nice to know
zcorpan_: btw, any chance you could make your script generate http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#index ?
it's an honesty sheet
Maybe the time people are spending debating the " " could be better used launching a DOS attack on w3schools
lol
Hixie: i don't have a script for it
ah, bummer
keeping it up-to-date manually helps me find mistakes in the spec :)
Hixie, I have some scripts that could be used for those
zcorpan_: :-)
zcorpan_: yes, I'm doing something like that now, but I set a seperate id for the object, to have less correlation between html and js, thx
Lachy: that would rock
well, some that are incomplete, but I'd written some for my HTML5 Reference
Lachy: i'm happy to adjust the markup if it would help
I doubt it would take much to modify them to output what you need
Hixie, the current requirements, especially the asterisk ones, are hard to automate
yes
i expect there would be some manual input
e.g. a configuration file, or some annotations in the html5 spec
Hixie, it would also be nice to have a really short description for each element, similar to what Mike has
Hixie, I will prrioritise those scripts, since I need to have the "List of elements" and "List of attributes" tables for the HTML5 reference too
Lachy: cool
annevk2: good point, let me add a column for that
but they're all here if you want to do it yourself http://dev.w3.org/cvsweb/html5/html-author/utils/
i'm going to prioritise getting feedback to zero
is going to prioritize keeping feedback above zero

jgraham, I remember that :-)

that's the superfriends
flying around in capes

hsivonen: I thought he did

Hixie: feel free to use verbatim any of the short descriptions from my draft that you want to
MikeSmith: thanks

one day
OK
would rather have a pimp cane than a cape
What would your super ability be?

combined with an exceptional ability to be able to make a bong out of any available materials

Philip`: X-ray vision
or better yet, XXX-ray vision
MikeSmith: btw, i was informed that the description of the <ruby> example we came up with was wrong.
MikeSmith: something about it not being kanji after all, but being hiragana
i was also told it was furigana
MikeSmith: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-ruby-element
Hixie: yeah, I saw that. I guess "furigana reading" is probably the most precise way to describe it.
MikeSmith: not hiragana?
can the reading be furigana?
thought the annotation itself was typographically furigana
but "reading"?
well, I think I originally suggested "kanji reading" (meaning the reading of the kanji, not that the reading itself was kanji)
but people pointed out that was ambiguous
what is the reading itself in?
I guess "reading in furigana" would be the least ambiguous
the reading you have in there now is hiragana
so wouldn't "reading in hiragana" be better?
furigana is the name of the typographical tool, right? not the letters?
it's more generally furigana
because you might have another case where it's in katakana
i'm talking specifically about the case in the example here
not anything generic
specifically, it's hiragana
ok
Hixie: I think to be as unambiguous as possible, it should be "annotated with its reading in hiragana"
k
Hixie: http://annevankesteren.nl/2006/01/fallback for the fallback discussion
what about it?
you could define two different terms for fallback
one for the kind of fallback that img and object use
and one for the kind that iframe and audio use
i think <applet> actually supports both kinds
i'm trying to get rid of the term altogether actually
ok
not trying very hard
but hard enough not to add anything new along those lines :-)
reading that again the terms content fallback and element fallback seems nice
s/seems/seem/
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1417683/add-html-5-doctype-to-xdocument-net
Hixie: when the UA supports no crypto for <keygen>, wouldn't it make sense to require the element to be an HTMLUnknownElement in that case?
how are authors supposed to check for support for keygen?
or are they expected to test support for ActiveX first?
lol
would prefer we didn't have HTMLUnknownElement
what do they do today?
hsivonen: see my e-mail
doesn't firefox recognize the 'loop' and 'autoplay' parameters in audio-tag?
Hixie: is it actually desirable to make it act like a form control when it has no crypto?
gsnedders: Do you have any good reason for that wish?
it's desierable to not have random other parts of scripts fail, yes
jgraham_: It just seems so ugly
gsnedders: Why?
Hixie: ok. let's see if IE9 implements those parts
jgraham_, it ought to be just HTMLElement
annevk2: It's not obvious to me why it makes a big difference
jgraham_: Adding new HTML elements it will lead to compat issues
jgraham_, HTMLUnknownElement is some Firefox invention that somehow started affecting other browsers much like crap IE once introduced

Hmm, it sounds like blocks just do boring const copies of stack variables
like what Java inner methods do
and not like real closures at all
(Actually I suppose that depends on what real closures are)
(but anyway it seems you can't do the equivalent of "sub adder { my $n = 0; return sub { return ++$n } }" without doing explicit heap allocation)
You mean they can't modify varibles in the outer scope
(...unless you mark the local variable with __block)
jgraham_: Yes (except with __block)
If you wanted to modify local variables in the outer scope, you'd really need garbage-collected heap-allocated stack frames
which isn't going to happen in C, so you can't modify them and it just copies their values into a per-block bit of memory
so that it doesn't matter when the stack frame gets popped
(At least I think that's how it works; please tell me I'm being stupid if I am)
that seems to be how they work
seems about the closest you get to real closures in C, really
Introducing type inference on return values seems weird, since nothing else in C does anything like that, as far as I'm aware
and C is not known for syntactic sugar
That's how I build be closures, at least
partly because it is easier and partly because it is much easier to define the behaviour
sub adder { $a = shift; return sub { return $a + shift; }};   sub add10 = adder(10);
being the notable example
eventually realises he should have done his earlier example in JS, like "function adder() { var n = 0; return function () { return ++n; } }"
